body_text.text: Coronavirus (COVID-19) that was first detected in China presented in the beginning 2 with a series of pneumonia cases. This virus has now been detected in more than 100 3 locations internationally [1] . Most recently, the focus of the attention has moved away 4 from Mainland China and the World Health Organization (WHO) has recognised 5 Europe as the new epicenter of the outbreak [2] . We are seeing the tragedy in Italy and 6 Spain and fast spreading in the US, creating havoc around the world. Healthcare 7 workers including doctors, nurses, and anesthesiologists, and health care support 8 workers are on the front line of caring for patients with confirmed or possible 9 infection with COVID-19, and have a high risk of exposure to this virus because of 10 shortages of personal protective equipment (PPE) in many countries [3] . It has been 11 challenging to protect health-care workers from exposure and the effectiveness of PPE 12 for health-care workers who take care of patients infected with the COVID-19 is 13 unclear [4] . Similarly at least 15 deaths are reported amongst the health-care 17 professionals in the UK. The surgical system faces many difficult questions, in this 18 sense; the experiences from China and the UK may represent an opportunity for the 19 other countries to plan for adequate measures in surgical system.

FIGREF1.text: strategies in the surgical system 22 The triage strategy to keep surgical staff out of clinic and decrease exposure when 23 they are not needed is a key protocol. China has learned important lessons from the 24 Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) in 2003. One effective measure in China 25 was the establishment of fever clinics for confirmed and suspected patients [7].

FIGREF2.text: Isolated wards and buildings (when possible) need to be set up to place newly 27 admitted confirmed and suspected patients. In this early phase of the coronavirus 28 pandemic, propagation of nosocomial infections lead to increased outpatients visits 29 occurred in multiple clinics of Wuhan city. Against this background, national triage strategies to screen for COVID-19 were developed. Normally, fever clinic is not 31 mandatory for patients with any acute respiratory symptoms or fever in China. During 32 the epidemic, in order to minimize unnecessary clinics and hospitals patient visits, 33 fever clinics are set up by repurposing existing ones in dedicated hospitals. Good 34 public access is essential. Medical staff needs high levels of protection and must be 35 well trained in the use of PPE. Use of a fever clinic potentially limits the risk of 36 health-care workers exposure to the virus because tasked expertise is concentrated. 37 The diverting function of a triage strategy makes more health-care workers available 38 to maintain workforce capabilities. Home care isolation can relieve the burden on 39 health-care workers in response to the large volume of suspected patients arriving at 40 clinics, but we do not generally recommend this because of the physical and mental 41 health risks for patients. 42 43 Limit outpatient visits 44 Hospitals should cancel or reduce unnecessary outpatient visits in order to reduce 45 COVID-19 transmission, shifting as much care as possible to virtual consultation. 46 Patients with suspicious symptoms should be separated from the rest of the patient 47 population in fever clinics. Social distancing is important in clinics, keeping the 48 distance between chairs in the waiting-room and the distance between doctors and 49 patients six feet apart. It is essential to provide surgical facemasks to all patients 50 especially during the examinations. Cleaners should utilize regular droplet precautions 51 (surgical mask, gloves, and gown) and disinfect all surfaces after each consultation. 52 Mandatory use of separate team in every clinic and ward can avoid health-care-related 53 transmission and maintain workforce capabilities by avoiding the necessary 54laboratory testing and fourteen-day self-quarantine required for those exposed to an 55 infected person or with any respiratory symptoms. We recommend that front-line 56 health care workers in the solation areas should be provided with isolated 57 accommodation. When their duty rotation finishes, they should be tested for 58 COVID-19 and self-quarantine before going back to their communities even if the 59 results is negative.

One asymptomatic patient undergoing neurosurgery in a hospital in 65 Wuhan infected 14 health care workers [9]. At that time, no health care workers did 66 not realize that this patient was infected by coronavirus and did not take appropriate 67 protective measures during the OR and wards. Asymptomatic patients can spread 68 COVID-19 with high efficiency. Therefore, reasonable measures, including tests and 69 isolation should be taken by surgeons to avoid asymptomatic transmission during 70 aerosol-generating surgical procedures. 71 72The availability of tests is still limited and many tests have high false negatives results.73 In China, nucleic acids test (PCR), antibodies test and chest CT scan are required to 74 be completed in one day before admission. Nucleic acids test, which is largely 75 affected by sampling procedure, has the highest false negative rates (sensitivity rate 76 30-50%). The novel coronavirus-specific IgM antibody can be tested positive in 3-5 77 days post-infection. Due to the limited laboratory testing capabilities, the diagnosis in 78 many clinics cannot be based solely on laboratory testing, therefore a combination 79 with chest CT (sensitivity rate nearly 60%) is proven to be effective during the early 80 stage of the outbreak in Wuhan. If all tests are negative, the patient can be placed in a 81 transitional ward waiting for another nucleic acid test in 24 hours. If the patient with 82 negative results again then they will be transferred to the general ward. Any suspected 83 positive patients should be placed in a dedicated building or ward. Patients with 84 uncertain results after all tests should be observed and quarantined for 14 days before 85 elective surgery.

FIGREF5.text: 89 healthcare facilities should develop plans for emergency surgery and referral plans for patients who do not need emergency care during COVID-19 epidemic. The plan must 91 ensure emergency patients with respiratory symptoms being triaged to fever clinic 92 (figure. 1). A more efficient and rapid emergency surgical procedure by experienced 93 staffs can potentially minimize the risk of exposure and resources exhaustion. 94 Designated operating areas must be allocated to confirmed COVID-19 patients or 95 patients who require urgent operation. 96 97 Decrease exposure of health care staffs in OR 98 Optimized intraoperative management is imperative to mitigate perioperative 99 transmission. Restrictive reception of staffs is an initial step to minimal unnecessary 100 exposure [11]. The number of staff (5-6 persons) in the dedicated operating theatre 101 should be minimized strictly. Surgeons should not be in the OR when perform 102 intubation which is considered as an aerosol generating procedure. Video 103 laryngoscope can avoid close contact of anesthetist with patient. Before the end of the 104 operation, it is recommended to clean the airway and oral secretions under deep 105 anesthesia, and remove the tracheal tube before the patient is awake [12]. The Society 106 of American Gastrointestinal and Endoscopic Surgeons (SAGES) and European 107 Association of Endoscopic Surgery (EAES) recently released their Recommendations 108 Regarding Surgical Response to COVID-19 Crisis. They highlighted the risk of virus 109 release during laparoscopy with pneumoperitoneum and strongly suggested the use of 110 devices to filter released carbon dioxide for aerosolized particles [13]. Smoke 111 evacuation systems with appropriate filters may reduce the risk of exposure, and using 112 electrosurgical equipment at the lowest effective power as possible, but the complete 113 elimination of surgical smoke is practically unrealistic. From the experiences we 114 gained in China, open surgery is preferred with a surgical team wearing full-body PPE.115 Laparoscopic surgery can be gradually performed for elective surgery in well 116 controlled area after the preoperative screening. Because of the shortage of PPE, it is 117 sometimes impossible to provide full-body PPE for all staff at all operations. For 118 facilities with comprehensive screening and isolation conditions, normal levels of 119 protection can be used including disposable surgical cap, N95 mask, work uniform, disposable medical protective uniform, disposable latex gloves and goggles. the massive outbreak of COVID-19 worldwide, many health care facilities 124 are facing shortages of PPEs and having to identify alternative ways for standard 125 practices [14]. In China, the lowest standard of PPE that the government 126 recommended for the staffs in general clinic or ward is surgical masks [15]. For fever 127 clinic or other high-risk area, N95 respirators and goggles are required. The Centers 128 for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) of US has released a series of 129 recommendations to optimize the application of PPE especially N95 respirators. The 130 ideal way to prevent airborne transmission is to use a combination of hierarchy 131 controls strategies, including elimination, substitution, engineering controls, 132 administrative controls and PPE [16]. Before engaging in any work of caring patients 133 with confirmed or suspected COVID-19, the staff must undergo strict training and be 134 certified by the facility to ensure that they know how to put on and remove PPE 135 correctly. To minimize the unnecessary change PPE, staff should reduce the frequency 136 of moving in and out of the isolation wards.

FIGREF6.text: care facilities in China have been forced to postpone or cancel cancer surgeries 140 so they can allocate resources on care of COVID-19. However, forced delays of 141 surgeries might increase the risk of cancer progression. Alternative treatment 142 approaches (neoadjuvant chemotherapy) for patients who can't receive timely surgery 143 should be considered. In order to limit the number of patients and the risk of 144 transmission, chemotherapy drugs administered through infusion can be changed to 145 orally administered drugs if available [17]. Cancer patients should be closely 146 followed-up, once any perforated, obstructed, or actively bleeding occur, emergency 147 surgery should be performed. All decisions to offer or defer surgery will be based on 148 clinical judgement and the actual situation of the hospital. Late stage of the epidemic 151 After three months of the start of epidemic, there have been few new COVID-19 152 cases in mainland China, and China has entered into the late stage of the epidemic. All 153 health care facilities have gradually started to provide health care services. Because 154 the spread of the virus in the community has not been completely blocked, the 155 facilities still need to limit the number of patients coming to the clinic through the 156 administrative controls. For example, promoting the use of telemedicine can help 157 triage patients to the appropriate clinics. Health care workers should obtain a 158 complete travel history and contact history of the patients before admission. For 159 patients who need non-urgent or emergency surgery, nucleic acids test, antibodies test 160 and chest CT scan are all necessary in high-risk area such as Wuhan. Nucleic acids 161test and antibodies test are not mandatory for patients in low-risk area, however chest 162 CT scan is mandatory in most hospitals even in low-risk area.
